clinical_study.official_title: Circle Dances in Elderly Caregivers of Patients With Alzheimer's Disease: A Controlled and Randomized Study

collaborator.agency: Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior.

brief_summary.textblock: The task of caring for an individual with Alzheimer's disease is often carried out by elderly caregivers who, due to their motor and psychosocial alterations due to the aging process, may also be exposed to the development of the frailty syndrome. Therefore, it is necessary to promote the engagement and adherence of these caregivers in physical activities. In this sense, circle dances have received attention, either as a modality of physical activity or therapy, and, although little studied, seem to be an appropriate type of intervention for the elderly caregivers. Thus, this study aims to evaluate the effect of 12 weeks of circle dances on cognitive, psychological, physical and frailty-related variables in elderly caregivers of Alzheimer's patients. It is expected that the practice of circle dances will be able to reduce stress levels and depressive symptoms of elderly caregivers; Reduce and / or maintain the perception of care overload and improve some functional components such as: mobility; balance; muscle strength of legs; walking speed; fatigue and level of physical activity.

study_design_info.masking_description: The outcomes assessor will not be aware of the allocation of each subject in the Control Group or Group Intervention.

primary_outcome.measure: Brazilian Version of the Short Physical Performance Battery
primary_outcome.description: Battery tests that evaluate the static balance; the speed of gait and lower limb muscle strength. Each test ranges from zero to four points, and the total score is obtained by summing the score of each test, ranging from zero to 12 points. The result can receive the following graduation: 0 to 3 points: incapacity or very poor performance; 4 to 6 points: low performance; 7 to 9 points: moderate performance; 10 to 12 points: good performance.

Test that evaluates the basic functional mobility through the time spent by the elderly to get up from a chair with arms, walk 3 meters and return to the chair, as well as the number of steps required to perform the activity. The shorter the time to perform the task, the better the mobility index. Thus, if the individual takes up to 20 seconds to complete the task, it is considered independent in the basic activities of daily living, and if it takes more than 30 seconds, it has an increased risk of falls and functional dependence.

secondary_outcome.description: The test battery proposed by Fried et al. (2001) than by evaluating unintentional weight loss; exhaustion; Decrease in manual grip strength and walking speed and low level of physical activity, the elderly can be classified as fragile, if they score in 3 or more criteria; Pre-fragile, score in 1 or 2 criteria or as non-fragile, if they do not score.

Portuguese version of the Instrument that evaluates the global cognitive function through individual tests of orientation and attention (18 points), memory (26 points), verbal fluency (14 points), language (26 points) and spatial visibility skills (16 points) . The overall score ranges from 0 to 100 points.

An instrument validated in Brazil that evaluates the presence of depressive symptoms in the elderly through a scale composed of 15 negative / affirmative questions, with a cut mark equal to five points.

An instrument translated into Portuguese and validated to evaluate the physical, psychological and social impact of the task of caring for a patient with mental illness. The scale is composed of 22 questions, whose scores can range from 0 to 88 points. Score below 21 points is classified as no overload; Of 21 and 40 points indicate moderate overload; Between 41 to 60, moderate to severe overload and ≥ 61 points, severe overload.

Reduced version, translated and validated in Brazil that measures how much the elderly evaluate the situations of their lives occurred in the last month as stressors. The total score can vary from 0 to 40 points, and the higher the score, the greater the stress.

other_outcome.description: Questionnaire structured as an interview with questions about sociodemographic aspects (sex, age, schooling, profession and marital status); General clinical condition (self report of pathologies, of medicines in use in the last 3 months and history of falls); information On the demand for care (time as caregiver, hours spent on patient care, time for diagnosis and staging of Alzheimer's disease).

The mass index will be measured (BMI), represented by the ratio between body mass and square of height (kg / m2) and waist-hip ratio (ICQ), determined by the relation between waist circumference - midpoint between the lower margin of the last palpable rib And the beginning of the iliac crest, and the hip - measured at the maximum circumference above the buttocks.

other_outcome.measure: Assessment of the Quality of Life in Alzheimer's Disease
other_outcome.description: Scale structured in three versions that relate to the quality of life of the elderly, caregiver and caregiver in relation to the patient. Each version can be used separately and a score for each can range from 13 to 52 points, the lower the score for a quality of life.

other_outcome.measure: List of reduced and illustrated states of mind
other_outcome.time_frame: After randomization, before starting each intervention session and at the end of each intervention session, over 12 weeks.
other_outcome.description: List that presents 14 figures of faces of the type "smile" representing expressions corresponding to the following moods: happy, active calm, light, pleasant, shy, full of energy, sad, spiritual, agitated, heavy, nasty, scared and useless.

arm_group.description: The 12-week circular dance program twice a week will be offered to the intervention group. Each dance class will last for an hour, and the number of participants per class will range from 10 to 15. An physical education professional with Circle Dances certified will lead the classes. The Circle Dances consist of a simple way of dancing choreographies of various peoples and cultures, adapted for a circle dance, hand in hand, where it is not necessary to know how to dance, because no technique or experience is required.

Participants in the control group will not receive intervention and will be instructed not to take part in any regular exercise programs during the study period. At the end of the study, if the benefits of the intervention are proven, Circular Dances classes will be offered to the control group twice a week for 12 weeks.

intervention.description: The Circle Dances consist of a simple way of dancing choreographies of various peoples and cultures, adapted for a circle dance, hand in hand, where it is not necessary to know how to dance, because no technique or experience is required. The choreographies challenges balance, motor coordination, cognitive function and could improve mobility; muscle strength of legs; walking speed and fatigue.

patient_data.ipd_description: The individual participant data collected in this study, such as age, gender, cognitive status, contact telephone and address is available in a database in order to facilitate the recruitment process of the population for the development of new studies.
